p: It is now well recognized that nonmotor symptoms are an integral part of the clinical spectrum of the disease [ 43–46] and may even antedate the clinical manifestation of cardinal motor features of PD by several years in a substantial proportion of patients[ 7–9, 47] ( Table 2). Considering Braak’s hypothesis that PD pathology first starts in extranigral sites, particularly the olfactory system, lower brainstem and peripheral autonomic nervous system [ 4, 5, 48], it is intriguing to note that recent clinical studies have found certain nonmotor symptoms such as constipation, dream enacting behaviour, and smell-loss preceding the onset of first motor complaints into time periods that are longer before motor onset as compared to other nonmotor complaints [ 7, 9].
